item.title: Total Solar Eclipse Interviews
item.description: On April 3, 2024, I spoke with 9 different local news stations around the country about the eclipse, eclipse safety, and how to get involved with citizen science projects with NASA! You too can learn more at go.nasa.gov/Eclipse2024. The contiguous US will be in a good location to see at least a partial eclipse, with 31 million people already living along the path of totality. Watch below! Fox4 KDFW Dallas-Fort Worth

I’m not Afraid of Anything Part of Your World

item.title: fitting PADs
item.description: For my recent studies on the evolution of electron pitch angle distributions (PADs) in Earth’s radiation belts, I developed a code to take Van Allen Probes MagEIS and REPT electron data and fit the PADs with a sin^n function. It fits PADs for every spin of the twin spacecraft. There is currently a Zenodo doi, so if you find this code useful, please cite! Get the package here

item.title: Seminar - Magnetospheric Seminar Series
item.description: In March, 2021, I gave a Magnetospheric Seminar Series talk on solid state detectors, titled “An experimentalist’s approach to solid state detectors.” You can watch it here and find more information regarding the seminar series here.

item.title: CuSP on Artemis
item.description: I worked on the CuSP (CubeSat to study Solar Particles), and am so excited to see it launch! The current launch date has been pushed back to September 27, but if that increases the chance for success, I’m glad for it. Here’s a link that talks about the CubeSats on Artemis. CuSP will be studying interplanetary ions. The CubeSat to study Solar Particles, or CuSP, will hitch a ride out of Earths orbit on #Artemis I.

item.description: “Engineer Allison Evans and graduate student scientist Ashley [Greeley] dress in ‘bunny suits’ for their work to install particle detectors on a CubeSat instrument. The Compact Radiation Belt Explorer (CeREs) will study the bands of energetic particles that surround Earth, known as the Van Allen radiation belts.” Read more about the #24Seven social media campaign for Earth Day 2016, here

item.title: Early Career Scientist Spotlight
item.description: “Be stubborn, both in pursuing research and finding the right opportunity. I honestly believe the most important characteristic of a scientist is stubbornly trucking along no matter what (followed closely by the ability to change their mind when confronted with new evidence).” Read the article on NASA’s website here!

item.title: Researchers track slowly splitting 'dent' in Earth's magnetic field
item.description: “One study, led by NASA heliophysicist Ashley Greeley as part of her doctoral thesis, used two decades of data from SAMPEX to show that the SAA is slowly but steadily drifting in a northwesterly direction. The results helped confirm models created from geomagnetic measurements and showed how the SAA’s location changes as the geomagnetic field evolves.”" Read the article on Science Daily here!

item.title: Physics Student Builds Space Weather Satellite
item.description: “Ashley Greeley is building a satellite. “I know,” said Greeley. “I tell people that and they always say, ’that sounds cool!’ — but seriously, it is really cool.” Read the article at catholic.edu here!

item.title: The Herky Jerky Weirdness of Earth's Magnetic Field
item.description: “But sometimes a satellite is just unlucky. Ashley Greeley, a postdoctoral scholar at NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, recalled a CubeSat that died shortly after launch. During start-up checks and the commissioning phase, “we think that an energetic particle hit it in the wrong place at the wrong time, and we never got data, unfortunately,” she said.” Read the article on EOS here!

item.title: First post
item.description: I am delving into the world of content management. I’m hoping to make my codes and projects more available to the public, and to anyone who is looking to replicate my results. Let me know if there’s anything you’re looking for that isn’t here, or if you need help deciphering my code. As a warning, just because I am open to sharing my code does not mean that it’s elegant.
